I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 

1. 
to Nepal for the Water Resources Project Preparatory Facility.1 
 
2. 
The  facility  will  support  the  Government  of  Nepal’s  efforts  to  ensure  that  critically 
important  water  resource  projects  are  implemented  efficiently  by  advancing  preparatory 
activities  in  a  systematic  manner,  through  planning  and  appraising  high-priority  projects  for 
potential funding by the government and development partners. This will contribute significantly 
to  improving  implementation  performance  of  the  ensuing  projects  by  reducing  the  gap  from 
project  approval  by  the  Board  of  Directors  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to 
commencement  of  improvement  works,  helping  to  achieve  the  intended  outcomes  efficiently 
and realizing their impact and benefits quickly.2 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Nepal,  largely  an  agrarian  economy,  is  highly  sensitive  to  changes  in  climate  and 
availability  of  natural  resources  including  water.3  While  water  resources  face  additional 
demands  with  the  increasing  amount  of  water  required  for  energy  and  urban  use  to  support 
continuing economic growth, irrigation still accounts for 87% of water use and water remains the 
most critical input for food security. Most opportunities to improve agricultural production  and, 
thus,  reduce  poverty  and  food  deficiencies  depend  on  improved  infrastructure  for  water 
resources,  improved  management  of  the  infrastructure,  improved  water  use  efficiency,  and 
protection  of  crops  and  infrastructure  from  water-induced  disasters  such  as  floods,  landslides, 
and land erosion. 
 
Climate change threatens to reduce the effectiveness of development initiatives across 
4. 
Nepal. In some regions, increasing drought will impair food security and affect the availability of 
water resources; while in others, increases in the intensity of rains will cause increased flooding 
and landslide risks threatening human security, water supplies, and infrastructure. In the hill and 
mountain regions in particular (accounting for two-thirds of the land area), reduced food security 
results in the increasing use of more and more marginal land for food production. This, in turn, 
results in increasing environmental instability in the fragile mountain ecological system through 
accelerated soil erosion and increased runoff during the monsoon season. On the other hand, 
access  to  water  for  irrigation  allows  intensive  food  crop  cultivation  on  higher  quality,  more 
productive  land,  thus  increasing  overall  food  production  and  forestalling  environmental 
degradation of less-productive marginal areas. The preparation of readily implementable water 
resource projects to address these issues is thus crucial for the water–food–energy nexus and 
for climate-resilient food security and environmental sustainability. 
 
5. 
The  provision  of  adequate  water  through  supplementary  irrigation  can  double  or  triple 
crop  yields  in  the  monsoon  season,  and  dry  season  irrigation  can  produce  crops  when  none 
could be grown before. The combination of effective and efficient land and water use can thus 
have  a  major  impact  on  food  security  and  environmental  stability.  To  this  effect,  since  the 
                                                 
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
2  The facility was prepared without project preparatory technical assistance. In 2010, ADB approved a similar project 
preparatory facility for the transport sector. ADB. 2010. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board 
of Directors: Proposed Grant to Nepal for the Transport Project Preparatory Facility. Manila. 

3  Government of Nepal, Ministry of the Environment. 2010. National Adaptation Programme for Action. Kathmandu. 

 2 

 

improved  system  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M), 

1980s, Nepal has significantly increased rural livelihoods through investment in water resource 
infrastructure,  improved  agriculture  technology  and  extension  services,  and  enhanced  rural 
access. However, at present, only 38% of the irrigated area is provided with irrigation water on a 
year-round basis and not all of this is used efficiently. On the other hand, during years of intense 
rainfall, both crops and infrastructure are likely to be damaged by catastrophic floods and fertile 
soils can be washed away. As a consequence, almost half of the districts, particularly from the 
hill  and  mountains  of  the  far-western,  mid-western,  and  eastern  development  regions,  are  still 
food deficient. 
 
6. 
Nepal’s  population  continues  to  grow  and,  with  the  current  growth  rate,  is  expected  to 
reach 38 million (from about 24 million) by 2025. This means that, for the country to remain food 
sufficient  and  avoid  serious  environmental  degradation  as  a  result  of  unstable  cultivation 
practices,  agricultural  production  will  have  to  continue  growing,  particularly  in  irrigated  areas. 
Indeed,  the  provision  of  year-round  irrigation,  both  as  supplementary  irrigation  during  the 
monsoon season and full irrigation during the dry season, is crucial to achieve the full potential 
of  the  agriculture  resources,  ensure  the  efficient  use  of  land  and  water,  and  prevent  food 
insecurity and further environmental deterioration. Further, with irrigation, the risk of crop failure 
is mitigated and farmers are provided with an incentive to invest in more productive farming and 
high-value  crops,  thus  increasing  the  efficient  and  effective  use  of  land  and  water  resources. 
However,  the  provision  of  physical  infrastructure  on  its  own  is  not  enough  to  ensure  efficient 
land  and  water  use.  For  irrigation  to  have  its  full  potential  impact,  irrigation  facilities  must  be 
complemented  with  improved  water  distribution  and  management,  strengthened  water  user 
associations, 
farming 
technologies  and  marketing,  and  increased  protection  from  catastrophic  floods  during  the 
monsoon season. 
 
The  government’s  2005  National  Water  Plan  (NWP)4  aims  to  increase  the  area  of 
7. 
irrigable land provided with irrigation facilities from the current 65% to 97% by 2027, an increase 
in year-round irrigation coverage from the current 38% of irrigated area to 67%, and an average 
cropping intensity increase within year-round irrigated areas from the current 140% to 193%. It 
also  aims  to  put  in  place  infrastructure  to  mitigate  predictable  water-induced  disasters  in  
20  districts  and  to  establish  functional  water-induced  disaster  warning  systems  throughout 
Nepal  by  2017.  An  important  facet  of  the  NWP  is  its  emphasis  on  integrated  water  resources 
management, which is recognized as a key principle governing water and energy development. 
 
ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  (CPS)  for  Nepal5  proposes  that  ADB  and  the 
8. 
government  explore  interventions  to  improve  food  security  including  supporting  greater 
availability  of  water  and  year-round  irrigation  to  help  mitigate  recent  erratic  rainfall  patterns.  It 
notes  that  ADB  will  (i)  introduce  disaster  screening  into  its  operations  in  Nepal  to  ensure  that 
new  investments  factor  in  disaster  risks,  and  maximize  mitigation  measures;  (ii)  assist  the 
government in strengthening the capacity of agencies for managing disaster risks; and (iii) help 
the  government  implement  ongoing  flood  damage  rehabilitation.  The  agriculture  and  natural 
resources  sector  road  map  for  the  CPS  further  notes  that  improved  access  to  year-round 
irrigation  would  enable  crop  diversification  and  higher  cropping  intensity,  thereby  helping  to 
reduce food security concerns. 
 
9. 
The  facility  will  address  several  factors  constraining  efficiently  upgrading  existing 
infrastructure for water resources, expanding coverage to new areas, and enhancing prevention 

improved 

                                                 
4  Government of Nepal. 2005. National Water Plan. Kathmandu. 
5  ADB. 2009. Country Partnership Strategy: Nepal, 2010–2012. Manila. 

 of water-induced disasters. These include the outdated Irrigation Master Plan (IMP),6 difficulty in 
identifying  projects  for  funding  without  well-defined  priorities,  and  lengthy  time  needed  to  start 
up and implement projects after their approval. For example, the Community-Managed Irrigated 
Agriculture  Sector  Project7  had  a  very  slow  start;  physical  improvement  works  on  irrigation 
systems commenced 3 years after approval.8 The facility is designed to overcome this type of 
implementation delay for future projects. It will also address the need, identified in the NWP and 
the  CPS,  to  pay  greater  attention  to  climate-induced  disasters,  especially  in  the  context  of 
Nepal’s vulnerability to climate change. In this context, the design of individual projects and their 
components as well as the selection of subprojects will be based partly on the need to take into 
account and mitigate the likely impacts of climate change. 
 
10. 
The facility conforms to recommendations made in the recent sector assistance program 
evaluation  in  Nepal,  which  recommends  an  increased  strategic  focus  in  supporting  the 
agriculture and natural resources sector by increasing investment in rural infrastructure such as 
irrigation,  rural  roads,  and  markets.9  The  facility  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  Operational  Plan  for 
Sustainable  Food  Security  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific,10  which  recommends  enhancing  ADB’s 
multisector food security engagement with improved water productivity and increased resilience 
against natural disasters (flood and drought risk management) as major contributors; and Water 
Operational  Plan,11  which  aims  to  improve  efficient  use  of  water  and  enhance  agricultural 
productivity. By producing more food with less water and preventing water-induced damage and 
disasters to productive land, infrastructure, and property, the facility will be fully consistent with 
the  priorities  of  the  government  and  ADB  to  enhance  climate  resilience,  ensure  food  security, 
promote environmental sustainability, and promote inclusive economic growth. 
 
liaison,  cooperation,  and  synergies  with  other 
11. 
development  partners,12  in  particular  with  the  World  Bank  and  the  Nepal  Risk  Reduction 
Consortium,13  on  water-induced  disaster  prevention.  ADB  missions  have  met  development 
partners that are active in promoting water use efficiency and preventing water-related disasters 
in  Nepal.  The  project  design  has  benefited  from  development  partner  experience  and  lessons 
from similar projects. 
 
B. 

facility  will  actively  pursue 

Impact and Outcome 

The 

12. 
The  impact  will  be  more  water-efficient  and  climate-  and  disaster-resilient  food 
production  system.  The  outcome  will  be  improved  readiness  of  water  resource  management 
projects for implementation. 
 

                                                 
6  Government  of  Nepal.  1990.  Irrigation  Master  Plan.  Kathmandu  does  not  take  into  account  changes  in  land  use, 
changes in water use, and changes in water policy including a focus on integrated water resources management. 
7  ADB. 2004. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to the Kingdom 

of Nepal for the Community-Managed Irrigated Agriculture Sector Project. Manila. 

8  This was largely because, except for a very small number of sample subprojects, each individual irrigation scheme 

covered by the project had to be prepared, appraised, and designed after the project was approved. 

9  ADB. 2009. Agriculture and Natural Resources Sector in Nepal. Manila. 
10 ADB. 2009. Operational Plan for Sustainable Food Security in Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
11 ADB. 2011. Water Operational Plan, 2011–2020. Manila. 
12 Development Coordination (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
13 The  Nepal  Risk  Reduction  Consortium,  comprising  ADB,  the  International  Federation  of  the  Red  Cross,  the  Red 
Crescent Societies, the United Nations Development Programme, the United Nations Office for the Coordination of 
Humanitarian  Affairs,  the  United  Nations  International  Strategy  for  Disaster  Reduction,  and  the  World  Bank,  was 
formed in May 2009 to support the government in developing a disaster risk reduction action plan. 

3 

 

 4 

C. 

Outputs 

13. 
The outputs will be (i) detailed feasibility studies for high-priority water resource projects; 
(ii) improved environmental, social, and technical capacity of the Department of Irrigation (DOI) 
and  the  Department  of  Water-Induced  Disaster  Prevention  (DWIDP);  (iii)  updated  IMP;14  and  
(iv) efficient facility management. The outputs will be delivered through four components. 
 

1. 

Detailed Feasibility Studies 

The facility will aim to prepare detailed feasibility studies for three projects15 for potential 

14. 
financing by ADB and other development partners: 
 

(i) 

Mid-Hills  Irrigation  Efficiency  Improvement  Project16  to  upgrade  inefficient 
irrigation  schemes  to  fully  functional  status;  build  up  farmer  water  user  groups 
through appropriate community organization and training for sustained O&M; and 
provide  training  and  support  for  enhanced  agricultural  production,  improved 
marketing, and value addition on the improved schemes; 

(ii)  Water-Induced  Disaster Prevention  Project  in  the  Naryani  river  basin,  based  on 
water-induced  hazard  mapping,  to  prevent  and  alleviate  risks  to  human 
settlements and damage to productive agricultural land by flood, sedimentation, 
riverbank erosion, and landslides; it will include funding for water-induced hazard 
mapping for the rest of Nepal as required by the NWP; and 
Terai  Irrigation  Efficiency  Improvement  Project  to  rehabilitate  and  restore 
schemes  to  full  productive  capacity  and  develop  groundwater  irrigation  using 
deep and shallow tubewells. 

(iii) 

 
15. 
Projects  will  be  prepared  to  the  detailed  feasibility  stage,  including  technical  study; 
safeguard screening and plan preparation; gender equality and social inclusion (GESI) analysis, 
and GESI action plan preparation; and economic and financial analyses of at least 30% of the 
subprojects  for  project  readiness,  thereby  advancing  activities  that  would  normally  occupy  the 
first 1–2 start-up years of project implementation. Specific climate change adaptation measures 
will be considered in the design of each project. Prior to and during these activities, extensive 
and  intensive  consultations  will  be  held  with  potential  beneficiaries  and  measures  taken  to 
strengthen water user associations in preparation for physical implementation subproject works. 
 

2. 

Improved  Department  of  Irrigation  and  Department  of  Water-Induced 
Disaster Prevention  

16. 
The facility will enhance the capacity of DOI and DWIDP staff through formal and on-the-
job training (including participation in project preparation). It will strengthen and upgrade DOI’s 
Environment  Section  as  a  social  and  environment  section  and  establish  a  social  and 
environment desk within DWIDP, providing (i) clear terms of reference for the section and desk, 
(ii)  environmental  and  social  safeguard  guidelines  on  safeguard  planning  and  implementation, 
and (iii) GESI guidelines for planning and implementation. All technical staff of the DOI section 

                                                 
14 The IMP updating will consider recommendations of the agriculture development strategy, of which ADB is leading 
the  preparation,  including  a  strategy  for  irrigated  agriculture,  an  irrigation  sector  policy,  and  a  regulatory  and 
investment road map. 

15 No project preparatory technical assistance will be required for projects prepared by the facility. The facility can use 
any savings identified by the midterm review to prepare priority projects as agreed to by ADB and the government. 
16 This project is programmed in ADB. 2011. Country Operations and Business Plan: Nepal, 2012–2014. Manila under 

the title Rehabilitation and Management Transfer of Medium Irrigation Schemes for approval in 2014. 

 

 and  the  DWIDP  desk,  and  staff  from  other  operations  areas  of  DOI  and  DWIDP  and  the 
Environment  Section  of  the  Ministry  of  Irrigation  (MOI)  will  be  provided  with  training  on  the 
safeguard and GESI-related policy, principles, and requirements. 
 
The facility will also conduct a comprehensive assessment of the institutional capacity of 
17. 
DOI and DWIDP and prepare a needs assessment report, including capacity development plan, 
staffing, and budget. Based on the needs assessment, DOI and DWIDP staff will be trained in 
new  and  innovative  technology,  information  science,  and  management.  To  complement  their 
role in mapping water-induced hazards and other related activities, training will be provided for 
DWIDP  and  DOI  staff  in  remote  sensing,  geographic  information  system  mapping,  disaster 
preparedness planning, and information sharing. 
 

3. 

Updated Irrigation Master Plan  

18. 
The  facility  will  support  updating  of  the  IMP  to  reflect  changes  in  land  use,  water  use, 
agricultural  technology,  irrigation,  and  water  resource  policy  and  legislation,  and  develop  an 
inventory of high-priority irrigation infrastructure investment needs to guide the government and 
development  partners  in  identifying  and  prioritizing  future  investments  in  this  important 
subsector.  The  development  partners  active  in  promoting  the  water–food–energy  nexus  in 
Nepal will set up an advisory group to work with the government on updating the IMP. 
 

4. 

Efficient Facility Management 

19. 
A facility management unit (FMU) will be set up with qualified staff within DOI. Support to 
the FMU will be provided in terms of office space, equipment and furniture, transport, operating 
expenses, and consulting services to help manage project implementation. 
 
D. 
 
20. 
 

The facility is estimated to cost $13.8 million (Table 1).

23. 
DOI will be the main implementing agency; DWIDP will be the implementing agency for 
the  water-induced  hazard  mapping  and  preparation  of  the  Water-Induced  Disaster  Prevention 
Project. 
 
24. 
The  facility  will  require  inputs  of  five  consulting  service  packages  with  firms:  three  for 
project  preparation,  one  for  updating  the  IMP,  and  one  for  facility  management  and  capacity 
building. To speed up implementation of the facility, the government has asked ADB to help with 
consultant  recruitment  up  to  the  point  of  contract  negotiation  for  three  packages:  (i)  facility 
                                                 
17 Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

6 

 

 management  and  capacity  building,  (ii)  preparation  of  the  Mid-Hills  Irrigation  Efficiency 
Improvement  Project,  and  (iii)  water-induced  hazard  mapping  and  preparation  of  the  Water- 
Induced Disaster Prevention Project. The facility management consultants will support DOI with 
recruiting the remaining two consulting service packages. All procurement will be carried out in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time),  and 
consultants  will  be  recruited  using  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  on  a  90:10  ratio18  in  line 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Technical 

The projects to be prepared under the facility will be subject to full technical assessment. 
25. 
This  will  include  the  availability  and  quality  of  surface  water  or  groundwater  for  irrigation;  the 
appropriate design of water control structures including designs for flood resistance and climate 
change  adaptation;  the  use  of  easily  obtained  construction  materials;  the  level  of  O&M 
responsibility  devolved  to  water  users;  construction  quality  assurance;  linkage  to  agriculture 
intensification,  diversification,  and  commercialization  activities;  and  incorporation  of  effective 
design innovations. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 

26. 
All ensuing projects to be prepared by the facility will be assessed for their economic and 
financial viability as well as sustainability, in accordance with ADB's Guidelines for the Economic 
Analysis of Projects,19 assessing the economic life of the schemes and identifying the economic 
benefits  of  each  investment  scheme  comparing  the  with-  and  without-project  situations.  The 
financial  analysis  will  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  the  Financial 
Governance  and  Management  of  Investment  Projects  Financed  by  ADB,20  calculating  the 
financial  internal  rate  of  return  for  the  overall  investment  and  establishing  financial  viability  by 
comparing  the  financial  internal  rate  of  return  with  the  cost  of  capital,  taking  into  account 
financial costs and benefits. 
 
C. 

Governance 

27. 
Financial  management  and  procurement  capacity  assessments  were  undertaken  for 
DOI. No substantive risks are identified. DOI has implemented numerous development partner-
assisted  projects  including  the  prior  Community-Managed  Irrigated  Agriculture  Sector  Project 
and has the organizational structure, skills, financial management, and procurement system to 
implement the facility. 
 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
28. 
with MOI, DOI, and DWIDP. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are 
described  in  the  PAM  (footnote  18).  In  the  interest  of  transparency  and  equal  opportunity,  all 
requirements for consulting services and goods procurement will be published on the MOI and 
DOI  websites,  and  an  FMU  officer  will  be  delegated  to  be  the  contact  point  for  queries  and 

                                                 
18 A 90:10 ratio is necessary due to the importance of ensuring high-quality preparation of the ensuing projects and 

19 ADB. 1997. Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. Manila. 
20 ADB. 2002. Guidelines for the Financial Governance and Management of Investment Projects Financed by ADB. 

the IMP. 

Manila. 

7 

 

 8 

 

complaints  with  regard  to  procurement,  consulting  services  recruitment,  and  implementation 
activities. 
 
D. 

Poverty and Social 

29. 
The facility (comprising the preparation of investment projects, updating of the IMP, and 
capacity building) is not expected to have any negative poverty or social impacts. The projects 
to be prepared by the facility are expected to have major positive impacts on poverty reduction, 
gender  equality,  and  social  inclusiveness.  These  will  be  achieved  through  increases  in 
agricultural production, which will enhance food security in deficit areas, generate employment, 
promote  equal  opportunity  and  wages,  and  increase  rural  incomes.  Awareness  and  training 
sessions will enhance the participation of farmers (including women and marginalized farmers) 
and  increase  their  capacity  in  operation  and  management  of  irrigation  schemes.  A  change  to 
higher  value  crops  will  increase  income  and  employment  opportunities,  while  increased 
production overall will generate employment through processing and marketing activities, many 
of which are traditionally undertaken by women. 
 
30. 
Follow-on  projects  will  be  prepared  in  compliance  with  ADB's  Policy  on  Gender  and 
Development  (1998)  and  ADB's  Handbook  on  Social  Analysis.21  Gender,  consultation  and 
participation,  labor,  and  other  social  risks  relating  to  follow-on  projects  will  be  assessed,  and 
mitigation  plans  will  be  prepared  to  address  those  issues  during  project  preparation.  A  GESI 
action framework was prepared to ensure GESI responsiveness in ensuing projects. It is to be 
applied  as  a  guideline  in  the  development  of  a  GESI  action  plan  during  project  preparation.22 
Based  on  the  guideline,  gender  and  social  analysis  will  be  undertaken  for  ensuing  projects  to 
determine how women and traditionally excluded groups will be impacted by the projects. 
 
E. 
 
Since  the  facility  mainly  entails  studies  and  the  preparation  of  candidate  projects  for 
31. 
funding  as  well  as  some  capacity-building  activities,  and  will  not  involve  any  physical 
implementation,  the  safeguard  categories  for  the  environment,  involuntary  resettlement,  and 
indigenous peoples  are  all  “C.”  In  general,  most  of  the  ensuing  projects  are  not  anticipated  to 
entail any significant environment, involuntary resettlement, or indigenous peoples issues. Most 
of  the  investments  in  water  resource  management  are  likely  to  entail  the  upgrading  and 
improved  usage  of  existing  infrastructure  or  environmental  improvements  through  flood 
protection  and  water-induced  disaster  risk-reduction  measures.  Nonetheless,  a  full  review  and 
assessment  of  safeguard  issues  along  with  the  preparation  of  mitigation  measures  will  be 
included  in  each  of  the  preparatory  studies,  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009) and government guidelines, regulations, and policies. 
 
One  positive  aspect  of  the  facility’s  capacity-building  activities  is  that  it  will  include 
32. 
upgrading  DOI’s  Environment  Section  to  a  social  and  environment  section  and  establishing  a 
social  and  environment  desk  within  DWIDP.  Training  in  safeguard  measures  for  staff  of  MOI, 
DOI, and DWIDP will strengthen safeguard concerns in project preparation and implementation. 
 
33. 
To  ensure  environmental  and  social  safeguards  of  ensuing projects,  the  environmental 
assessment  and  review  framework,  resettlement  framework,  and  indigenous  peoples  planning 

Safeguards 

                                                 
21 ADB. 1994. Guidelines for Incorporation of Social Dimensions in Projects. Manila; ADB. 2007. Handbook on Social 

Analysis. Manila. 

22 Gender Action Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

 framework23 were prepared to guide due diligence on projects to be prepared under the facility. 
Each subproject under the projects to be prepared by the facility will be subject to environmental 
and  social  screening  to  avoid  adverse  impacts  such  as  encroaching  on  the  habitats  of  critical 
biodiversity  and  ecologically  sensitive  protected  areas,  indigenous  peoples,  sites  of  historical 
and  cultural  value,  and  areas  vulnerable  to  hazards  like  landslide  and  flood.  Subprojects  with 
category A impacts in terms of the environment, resettlement, or indigenous peoples will not be 
included in the scope of any projects prepared under the facility. 
 
F. 
 
34.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4. The integrated benefits 
and impacts of the project are expected to outweigh the potential costs from risks. 
 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 

Mitigating Measures 

Risks 

Natural disasters and 
climate change 

Disaster and climate change risk screening was conducted to assess the exposure 
of  the  Water  Resources  Project  Preparatory  Facility  to  climate-induced  risk  and 
natural disasters. 
Water-induced hazard mapping to be undertaken under the facility will identify areas 
of major river basins most prone to natural disasters and negative impacts of climate 
change. 
The projects to be prepared under the facility will help farmers adapt to long periods 
of drought through improved irrigation and water use efficiency in subproject areas. 
The  social  mobilization  and  capacity  development  program  under  the  ensuing 
projects will help farmers and DOI and DWIDP staff better understand the impacts 
of climate change, and identify adaptation and mitigation measures. 
The  establishment  of  the  FMU  will  be  accelerated  through  the  use  of  advance 
procurement and retroactive financing for office equipment, vehicles, and consulting 
services. 
The government has included the facility in the budget for fiscal year 2013. 
The  facility  design  entails  strong  ADB  involvement  in  the  recruitment  of  the  first 
three of five packages of consulting services. 
Management  and  capacity-building  supports  are  provided  to  the  FMU  to  assist  in 
recruiting  the  other  two  packages and  in  supervising  consulting service  inputs and 
monitoring the output. 
Full safeguards and gender equality and social inclusion frameworks were prepared 
so  that  consultants  have  a  precise  guide  to  follow  while  preparing  safeguard  and 
gender aspects of the ensuring projects and of the updated Irrigation Master Plan. 

Delays to the start-up 
of facility 
implementation 

Delays in consultant 
recruitment and poor 
quality of consulting 
services provided 

ADB  =  Asian  Development  Bank,  DOI  =  Department  of  Irrigation,  DWIDP  =  Department  of  Water-Induced  Disaster 
Prevention, FMU = facility management unit. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 

IV. 

ASSURANCES 

 
35. 
The  government  and  MOI  have  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the  facility  shall 
conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and grant documents. 
 

                                                 
23 Environmental  Assessment  and  Review  Framework,  Resettlement  Framework,  Indigenous  Peoples  Planning 

Framework (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

9 

 

 The  government  and  MOI  have  agreed  with  ADB  on  certain  covenants  for  the  facility, 

36. 
which are set forth in the grant agreement. 
 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

37. 
I am satisfied that the proposed grant would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  grant  not 
exceeding $11,000,000 to Nepal from ADB’s Special Funds resources for the Water Resources 
Project  Preparatory  Facility,  on  terms  and  conditions  that  are  substantially  in  accordance  with 
those set forth in the draft grant agreement presented to the Board. 
 
 
 

Haruhiko Kuroda 
President 
 

29 June 2012
